accordion.accordion_title: What is quetiapine and how does it work?
accordion.accordion_intro: Quetiapine is an antipsychotic drug (atypical type) that is used to treat certain mental/mood disorders. It works by rebalancing neurotransmitters in the brain.

accordion.accordion_title: What are the uses of quetiapine?
accordion.accordion_intro: Quetiapine is used to treat mental/mood disorders, such as schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. It can decrease hallucinations, improve your ability to concentrate, help you think clearly and positively, and feel less nervous. It can also improve mood, sleep, appetite, and energy.

Quetiapine should be taken as per the doctor’s recommendation. Typically, it is taken orally 2 times a day at doctor prescribed doses, based on your condition. You may be told to start at a low dose and gradually raise the dose, so your body can adjust.

accordion.accordion_title: What are the side effects and risks of quetiapine?
accordion.accordion_intro:
Quetiapine may cause:

  • Constipation
  • Drowsiness
  • Upset stomach
  • Weight gain
  • Blurred vision
  • Dry mouth
  • Increased blood pressure
accordion.accordion_content: Consult a doctor if any of your side effects worsen. If you experience any more serious side effects, including restlessness/constant need to move, shakiness, thoughts of suicide, difficulty swallowing, persistent nausea/vomiting, yellowing of the skin or eyes, or interrupted breathing during sleep, speak to your doctor immediately.

accordion.accordion_intro: Since quetiapine can cause blood sugar levels to rise, diabetics should avoid it or ensure you are being appropriately monitored. If you have a history of a known allergy to quetiapine, enlarged prostate, substance abuse, eye cataracts, liver disease, seizure disorder, or thyroid problems, you may want to discuss other treatment options.
accordion.accordion_content: If you have any questions about the medication, you can speak to a doctor on Maple by registering for an account.

accordion.accordion_intro: Seroquel does expire. It has a shelf life of approximately 3 years from the time of manufacturing. Most doctors recommend discarding unused prescriptions one year from the time it’s dispensed, because they’re unable to guarantee the continued potency of the medication. It’s not dangerous to take expired seroquel, but it will be less effective and may not provide the desired results.
